instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.820-00426: What is 820-00426? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CHGR_PHASE: What is CHGR_PHASE? CHGR_PHASE is charger voltage chopped up into individual slices prior to smoothing where it becomes PPBUS_G3H.
definitions.R7105: What is R7105? resistor between charger and CHGR_DCIN pin of ISL6259, if CHGR_DCIN is low then this resistor is probably blown. When PPBUS_G3H is low or missing this is something to check if your model has CHGR_DCIN along R7005. .
definitions.Q7180: What is Q7180? Inrush limiter transistor that must be told by the ISL6259 that it is safe to allow charger voltage to pass through to the computer. This needs CHGR_AGATE and CHGR_SGATE to be pulled down in order for it to close and allow voltage through to the system, current sensing failures as well as ISL6259 failures can cause this to happen. .
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.C7125: What is C7125? Capacitor between CHGR_BOOT and CHGR_PHASE important for bootstrapping creation of PPBUS_G3H on 2013-2015 macbook pros.
definitions.R7121: What is R7121? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7122: What is R7122? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00426</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - charging circuit - <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> gets warm
threads.message:
Hi,
Came in with <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> blown. Replaced it, <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR>, <TRANSISTOR>Q7135</TRANSISTOR>, <TRANSISTOR>Q7155</TRANSISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7105</RESISTOR> (measured kohm instead of 20ohm) also. <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> got warm so I replaced Inrush Limiter mosfets from a donor board (in this model there are 2 mosfets but in schematics it shows only one - <TRANSISTOR>Q7180</TRANSISTOR>). <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> still gets warm. Measured resistance on every pin on <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>  and nothing is wrong.
I tried charging the battery and <SIGNAL>CHGR_PHASE</SIGNAL> measures about 13,2V which normally is 12,6V.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00426</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - charging circuit - <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> gets warm
threads.message:
Did you check exact voltage at F7140/41?

Post exact resistance between pins 17/18 and 27/28.
Also post basic voltages; pins 1, 2, 3, 9, 12, 13, 15, 17, 19, 20, 27.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00426</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - charging circuit - <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> gets warm
threads.message:
Strange. Now voltage at F7140/41 is 4V. <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> still gets hot.
Resistance between pins 17 and 18 is 3,8 ohm.  Resistance between pins 27 and 28 is 22,8 ohm.
Pin:
1=0V
2=18,9V
3=3,4V
9=0V
12=3,4V
13=3,34V
15=0,067V
17=4,1V
19=4,99V
20=4,6V
27=20V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00426</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - charging circuit - <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> gets warm
threads.message:
"19=4,99V
20=4,6V"
Seems to have bigger difference than expected there.
Try abother <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP>.
Be sure <CAPACITOR>C7125</CAPACITOR> is OK.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00426</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - charging circuit - <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> gets warm
threads.message: You had right. Pin 23 and 25 (<SIGNAL>CHGR_BOOT</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>CHGR_PHASE</SIGNAL>) are shorted (0ohm between) and <RESISTOR>R7121</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7122</RESISTOR> measures in kohm in stead of 20 ohm before.  just replaced <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> and after plugging power in measured 1,6V on <SIGNAL>CHGR_PHASE</SIGNAL>. Disconnected power and <SIGNAL>CHGR_BOOT</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>CHGR_PHASE</SIGNAL> again shorted.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00426</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - charging circuit - <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> gets warm
threads.message:
"replaced <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> and after plugging power"
NEVER do this again.
After replacing burnt component, check first in diode mode around it.

This "short" may not exist; is how the chip blocks high-side MOSFET, when detects a problem.
Did you check <CAPACITOR>C7125</CAPACITOR>?
<RESISTOR>R7121</RESISTOR>/22 can both burn only if bad <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP>; less chance that <CAPACITOR>C7121</CAPACITOR>/22 get shorted at same time...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00426</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - charging circuit - <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> gets warm
threads.message:
I have checked in diode mode first :)
It seems that replacing <CHIP>U7190</CHIP> (P5V1) was the problem all the time. Now stable 5,1V at <SIGNAL>P5V1_CHGR_VDD</SIGNAL> and  <SIGNAL>P5V1_CHGR_VDDP</SIGNAL>.
<CHIP>U7100</CHIP> doesn't get hot and the battery is charging.
Thanks a lot for your help (y)
